info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 10 at 4:09AM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...STRONG WIND AND ACCUMULATING SNOW TONIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT... A winter storm system will cross from the northwest with strong winds over portions of northern and central New Mexico tonight through Thursday night, and accumulating snow for many locations along and west of the central mountain chain late tonight through Thursday evening. Southwest winds will begin to strengthen tonight with gusts reaching near 50 mph over the mountains. Then, those strong winds will shift out of the west and northwest Thursday and Thursday night, while spreading to many lower elevation locations as well. The strongest winds are expected over the south central mountains and adjacent high plains where gusts may exceed 60 mph tonight through Thursday night, producing dangerous crosswinds, and potentially damaging structures and powerlines. The strong winds will blow and drift snow making travel hazardous. Models are in good agreement on a few to several inches of snow over the western mountains, northwest areas, and north central areas mostly on Thursday. The heaviest snow amounts may reach around 10 inches throughout the Tusas Mountains, and on higher peaks elsewhere across the northern and western mountains. In addition, bitterly cold wind chill temperatures are forecast with readings generally varying from the single digits below zero to the teens above zero tonight into Thursday morning, then from near 20 degrees below zero to the single digits above zero Thursday night into Friday morning. Travelers and those planning outdoor activities should monitor the weather forecast over the next few days, and remain alert for any Watches, Warnings, and Advisories that are issued, so you are not caught off guard by this potentially dangerous winter storm.
